chapter: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question:
Question 1: A 4-month-old child was brought with a history of recurrent episodes of jaundice. Blood 
investigations were suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. Which of the following liver 
function test findings is likely to be seen here?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario describes recurrent hemolysis in a patient with hereditary 
spherocytosis leading to jaundice. In hemolytic conditions, only the unconjugated/ indirect 
bilirubin is raised and conjugated/direct bilirubin remains normal i.e. <15% of total bilirubin. Bilirubin is synthesized from heme which is released primarily from the breakdown of old RBCs. 
This bilirubin is in its unconjugated form. It enters the circulation and reaches the liver. It is 
converted to conjugated bilirubin which is then secreted into the biliary tree. Therefore, in a healthy person, most of the circulating bilirubin is unconjugated/indirect bilirubin. 
Hence, the normal liver function tests show indirect bilirubin >85% and direct/conjugated 
bilirubin <15% of the total bilirubin. The normal bilirubin values are as follows: • Total bilirubin levels - 1 to 1.5 mg/dL 253 
Sold by @itachibot • Direct bilirubin - <0.3 mg/dL
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question:
Question 2: A 2-week-old baby presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin. Investigations revealed 
markedly elevated direct bilirubin levels. Which of the following conditions should be 
suspected in the newborn?
questions.explanation:
The raised direct bilirubin levels indicate conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Among the given 
options, biliary atresia causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Biliary atresia is a disorder characterised by destruction or absence of bile ducts in a newborn. It 
leads to obstruction to the flow of bile thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the 
circulation. Option B: Physiological jaundice of the newborn occurs due to immaturity of the newborn's liver. 
It is not able to conjugate the excess bilirubin produced after birth. It leads to unconjugated 
hyperbilirubinemia. Option C: Breast milk may contain certain factors that inhibit the conjugation of bilirubin leading 
to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Option D: Hemolytic disease of the newborn causes excess production of bilirubin due to 
hemolysis leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question:
Question 3: Investigations performed in a patient with recurrent jaundice gave the following results. What 
is the possible cause of jaundice in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The presence of urinary bilirubin and increased total bilirubin indicates conjugated 
hyperbilirubinemia. Among the given options, Dubin Johnson syndrome causes conjugated 
hyperbilirubinemia. Only conjugated bilirubin can appear in the urine because it is water-soluble and filterable by the 
kidney. Unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble and bound to albumin, hence it cannot be 
filtered by the kidney. Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia: • Increased bilirubin production- • Hemolytic anemias • Hematomas • Impaired bilirubin uptake and conjugation- • Gilbert syndrome • Crigler Najjar syndrome • Drugs - Probenecid, Rifampin Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia: • Hereditary cholestatic syndromes • Dubin Johnson syndrome • Rotor syndrome 254 
Sold by @itachibot • Biliary obstruction
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question:
Question 4: 247 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia?

options.d: Stone in the common bile duct

questions.explanation:
Probenecid causes impaired hepatic uptake of bilirubin which leads to unconjugated 
hyperbilirubinemia. Amoxicillin-clavulanate, acute hepatitis and stone in the common bile duct are causes that lead to 
mixed hyperbilirubinemia (both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin elevated) or 
predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemias. Levels of conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin are useful in determining pre-hepatic causes of 
jaundice but are not useful in differentiating between intrahepatic and post-hepatic causes of 
jaundice.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question:
Question 5: A 24-year-old woman presents with jaundice. She had been on OCPs for the past month. Her 
LFT and liver biopsy findings are given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS). The LFT describes 
conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with normal liver enzyme levels. The given image of microscopic 
examination of liver biopsy shows an accumulation of dark melanin-like pigment in the 
hepatocytes which is seen in this condition. DJS is an autosomal recessive condition causing defective expression of MRP 2 protein which is 
important for the biliary excretion of conjugated bilirubin. The patient has icterus but is otherwise 
asymptomatic. DJS also impairs biliary excretion of various compounds like epinephrine metabolites. The dark 
melanin-like pigment is derived from these metabolites causing the liver to appear black. Rotor syndrome is also an autosomal recessive condition causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia 
but it does not present with pigmentation of the liver. Gilbert and Crigler-Najjar syndromes are characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question: Question 6: What is the defect seen in patients with Rotor syndrome?

options.b: Mutation in organic anion transport protein

questions.explanation:
Rotor syndrome occurs due to mutation in OATP (organic anion transport protein) 1B1 and 1B3. Rotor syndrome is an inherited autosomal recessive disorder with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 
It is a benign disorder with mild elevation of bilirubin levels. It is similar to Dubin Johnson 
syndrome but the liver does not show any black pigmentation. No treatment is required for these 
patients.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question:
Question 8: In a patient with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which feature helps confirm the diagnosis 
of Crigler- Najjar syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Kernicterus is seen in Crigler-Najjar syndrome but not in Gilbert syndrome. Gilbert syndrome 
does not cause a significant elevation in unconjugated bilirubin to cause kernicterus. Crigler-Najjar syndrome and Gilbert syndrome are both caused by various mutations in the 
UGT1A1 gene. This leads to decreased activity of bilirubin UDP-glucuronosyltransferase enzyme 
leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Both are predominantly inherited in an autosomal 
recessive pattern. These syndromes present with jaundice in infants. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in these 
syndromes is not associated with any hemolysis. All the other liver function tests are usually 
normal. Crigler Najjar syndrome may lead to kernicterus causing severe brain damage. Liver 
transplantation is required without which the infant may not survive beyond 1-2 years of age. 
Whereas, Gilbert syndrome is a benign asymptomatic condition that does not need any 
intervention.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question:
Question 9: An infant presented with yellow discolouration of the skin, poor feeding, and seizures. 
Investigations revealed total bilirubin- 40 mg/dL and unconjugated bilirubin- 34 mg/dL. 
Phenobarbitone was administered while blood was being arranged for an exchange 
transfusion. However, there was no improvement. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with poor feeding and seizures is indicative of kernicterus. This 
accompanied with unconjugated hyperbilrubinemia is highly suggestive of Crigler-Najjar 
syndrome type 1. No improvement in bilirubin levels following the administration of phenobarbital further supports 
the diagnosis. 256 
Sold by @itachibot Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace enzyme activity and type 2 
having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to 
kernicterus and neurological damage. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. Kernicterus occurs because the unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble and hence crosses the 
blood-brain barrier. Phenobarbital is an enzyme inducer. Its administration can be used to differentiate between type 1 
and type 2 Crigler-Najjar. • Enzyme induction by phenobarbital leads to improved conjugation of bilirubin leading to a 
reduction in total bilirubin level in type 2 Crigler-Najjar syndrome. • No improvement is seen in type 1 as the enzyme activity is absent and therefore cannot be 
induced. Inherited unconjugated hyperbilirubinemias (Autosomal Recessive) include: Note: Rotor syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Crigler-Najjar type I

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following conditions is associated with increased activity of 5’- nucleotidase?
questions.explanation: 5■-nucleotidase is usually elevated in cholestasis. Enzymes elevated in cholestasis are : • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) • 5■-nucleotidase • -glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question: Question 12: Which among the following is the most specific indicator of liver cell injury?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, alanine aminotransferase is the most specific indicator of liver cell 
injury. Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) are indicators of liver cell 
injury. This is because ALT is found primarily in the liver, whereas, AST is found in the liver, 
cardiac muscle, skeletal muscle, kidneys, brain, pancreas, etc. GGT and ALP are enzymes that primarily reflect cholestasis.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question: Question 13: In a patient with acute viral hepatitis, what level of serum transaminases will you expect?
questions.explanation:
258 
Sold by @itachibot In a patient with acute viral hepatitis, serum transaminases are elevated to >1000 IU/L The normal levels of serum transaminases are 10-40 IU/L. Marked elevation of serum 
transaminases >1000 IU/L is seen in conditions with extensive hepatocellular injury. These 
include: • Viral hepatitis • Ischemic injury to the liver in conditions like acute heart failure • Toxin/drug-induced liver injury Minor elevations of serum transaminase levels up to 300 IU/L are non-specific and can be found 
in any liver disease.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question:
Question 14: A 64-year-old man with jaundice and abdominal pain was found to have an ALP level of 200 
mg/dL. His LFT reports from a month ago had shown an ALP level of 50 mg/dL. What is your 
inference? 250 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Could be due to fatty meal intake

questions.explanation:
A 4 fold rise of serum ALP (alkaline phosphatase) is suggestive of cholestatic liver disease. 
However, serum ALP levels cannot differentiate between extrahepatic and intrahepatic 
cholestasis. The normal range for serum ALP is considered 40-125 IU/L. Serum alkaline phosphatase is found 
in the liver, bone, small intestines, and placenta. Hence, a mild increase in ALP, i.e., 1 - 1.5 times 
normal, can be seen in these conditions: • Following a fatty meal intake - influx of intestinal alkaline phosphatase into the blood. Hence, 
the patient is advised to fast before the blood sample is collected for the test. • In pregnancy - placental ALP • In children - rapid bone growth • In elderly people over 60 years of age ALP can be raised even in conditions like metastatic bone disease, inflammatory bowel disease, 
Hodgkin's lymphoma, etc. Hence, it needs to be correlated with raised levels of 
gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT) and 5' nucleotidase which are more specific for liver disease.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following statements regarding liver enzymes is true?

options.a: ALT is raised to >1000 IU/L in cirrhosis
options.b: Absolute levels of aminotransferases correlate with the prognosis
options.c: AST:ALT ratio <1 is seen in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
options.d: AST:ALT ratio >1 is seen in chronic viral hepatitis

questions.explanation:
AST:ALT ratio <1 is seen in NAFLD (nonalcoholic fatty liver disease). The AST:ALT ratio can be interpreted as follows: Option A: Patients with cirrhosis have only mildly elevated or even normal levels of serum 
transaminases. Option B: Absolute levels of aminotransferases are not used for predicting prognosis. This is 
because there is a poor correlation between the degree of liver cell damage and the levels of 
aminotransferases. 259

questions.question:
Question 16: Liver function tests of a patient show isolated elevation of gamma-glutamyltransferase with 
other liver enzymes within normal limits. All of the following drugs could be responsible for 
this finding except:
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, penicillin does not lead to elevated gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT) 
levels. GGT is a microsomal enzyme. Hence, drugs that are microsomal enzyme inducers can lead to an 
increase in GGT levels. However, other liver enzyme levels will be normal. Therefore, an isolated 
rise in GGT level does not indicate cholestatic liver disease. Drugs that increase levels of GGT are: • Barbiturates • Carbamazepine • Ethanol • Griseofulvin • Rifampicin • Phenytoin
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following statements regarding prothrombin time is false?

options.a: Indicates prognosis in acute liver disease
options.b: Indicates prognosis in chronic liver disease
options.c: Measures factors II, V, VIII, X
options.d: Measures factors II, V, VII, X

questions.explanation:
Prothrombin time (PT) can help in estimating the levels of factors II, V, VII, and X. PT evaluates the extrinsic and the common pathway of coagulation. Factor VII is required in the 
extrinsic pathway and factors II, V, X are required in the common pathway. Coagulation factors are produced by the liver (except factor VIII) and they have a short half-life. 
Hence, they indicate the synthetic function of the liver and are very useful in assessing acute 
hepatic dysfunction. Factor VIII is produced by vascular endothelial cells. 260 
Sold by @itachibot Prolonged PT that is not corrected by vitamin K administration indicates poor prognosis in both 
acute and chronic liver disease.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question:
Question 18: Which among the following is a marker of chronic liver disease? 251 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Serum albumin is a marker of chronic liver disease because it is synthesized by the hepatocytes 
and has a long half-life of 18–20 days. Serum albumin is not a good indicator of acute or mild 
hepatic dysfunction. Hypoalbuminemia is more common in chronic liver disorders such as cirrhosis and usually 
reflects severe liver damage. In hepatitis, albumin levels <3 g/dL should raise the possibility of 
chronic liver disease. Prothrombin time is used to assess acute parenchymal liver disease. 5' nucleosidase is elevated in 
cholestasis. Elevation of ALP (<3 fold) is not specific to liver diseases.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following can be seen in a patient with chronic liver disease?
questions.explanation:
Chronic liver disease is associated with hypergammaglobulinemia. Chronic liver diseases with 
hypergammaglobulinemia include autoimmune hepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis, and alcoholic 
liver disease. The liver produces all globulins except gamma globulin which are produced by B cells. In chronic 
liver diseases like liver cirrhosis, there is impaired reticuloendothelial function in hepatic 
sinusoids. Hence the liver fails to clear the bacterial antigens. This causes an increased production 
of gamma globulin.
questions.chapter_heading: Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function

questions.question:
Question 21: In which of the following patients planned for a liver biopsy, would you not be required to use 
the transjugular approach?
questions.explanation:
Liver biopsy can be performed in a patient with splenomegaly via the percutaneous approach. When the percutaneous approach is not advisable, liver biopsy can be performed via the 
transjugular approach. In this approach, a cannula is inserted via the jugular vein which is then 
passed into hepatic veins through which the biopsy sample is taken. Therefore, any bleeding 
resulting from the procedure will drain into the hepatic veins. Indications of transjugular liver biopsy: • Percutaneous approach contraindicated • Significant ascites • Prolonged INR • Coagulopathies • Difficulty in accessing the liver via the percutaneous route • Morbid obesity 262 
Sold by @itachibot Alcoholic Liver Diseases and Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease
